title: Immune System Drugs That Fight Multiple Myeloma
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors
description: Multiple myeloma compromises the immune system, which can cause opportunistic infections. Learn about prescription drugs that can help improve immune system performance.
cleaned_text: With [multiple myeloma](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/multiple-myeloma/multiple-myeloma-symptoms-causes-treatment), your immune system takes a serious hit. That makes it much harder for you to fight infections. So your immune system is a focus in many treatments. Harnessing the immune system to fight diseases is called immunotherapy. There are many immunotherapy treatments your doctor will consider. You'll want to get familiar with what they do and how they work. Immunotherapy boosts the body's natural defenses in the fight against cancer. Some immunotherapy drugs boost the immune system to help the body fight the disease. Others suppress it to do the same thing. Still more destroy [cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/) cells directly or ease the side effects of other treatments. Immunomodulators These medicines recognize [cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/ss/does-this-cause-cancer) cells. They help your immune system point out and attack those cells. The three medications below are taken as pills. Your doctor may call them immunomodulators or immune-modifying drugs. [Thalidomide](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/drug-16389-thalidomide+oral.aspx)( [Thalomid](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/drug-16403-thalomid+oral.aspx)) lowers the blood supply to cancers. It was first used to treat myeloma in the late 1990s. Before that, it was used as a sedative and [nausea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting)medication for [pregnant](https://www.webmd.com/baby/default.htm)women until it was found to cause birth defects. [Lenalidomide](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/drug-94823-lenalidomide+oral.aspx)( [Revlimid](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/drug-94831-revlimid+oral.aspx)) was designed to be a stronger form of thalidomide. [Pomalidomide](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-163457/pomalidomide+oral/details)( [Pomalyst](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-163468/pomalyst-oral/details)) is the newest drug of this type approved by the FDA for multiple myeloma. It's similar to the others above. You're most likely to get it if you've received at least two prior treatments for multiple myeloma. These drugs share a few common side effects: - Low blood counts: These drugs can lead to conditions like: [Anemia](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/understanding-anemia-basics)(a lack of red [blood cells](https://www.webmd.com/heart/anatomy-picture-of-blood)), which can leave you feeling [tired](https://www.webmd.com/women/why-so-tired-10-causes-fatigue)and weak, among other problems - Leukopenia, a low [white blood cell count](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/white-blood-cell-count-low), which can make it hard to fight infections [Neuropathy](https://www.webmd.com/brain/nerve-pain-and-nerve-damage-symptoms-and-causes): Nerve damage can cause various things, from a pins-and-needles feeling to severe [pain](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/default.htm)in your arms and legs. [Blood clots](https://www.webmd.com/dvt/blood-clot-symptoms): You're more likely to get [blood clots](https://www.webmd.com/dvt/blood-clots)that can travel to your [lungs](https://www.webmd.com/lung/healthy-lungs-smokers-lungs)from your leg. Each drug also has more side effects that your doctor will discuss with you. CAR T-cell Therapy Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy involves versions of your T cells (white [blood cells](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/rm-quiz-blood-basics) that fight disease) that have had their genes changed so they attach to cancer cells. This is also called adoptive cell therapy. You might get [ciltacabtagen](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-183641/ciltacabtagene-autoleucel-intravenous/details) ( [Carvykti](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-183643/carvykti-intravenous/details/list-sideeffects)) if you've tried at least four other types of treatment. Monoclonal Antibodies These are human-made. They're supposed to work on one type of target. [Daratumumab](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-170456/daratumumab-intravenous/details)( [Darzalex](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-170471/darzalex+intravenous/details)) or [daratumumab and hyaluronidase](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-179276/daratumumab-hyaluronidase-fihj-subcutaneous/details)( [Darzalex Faspro](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-179283/darzalex-faspro-subcutaneous/details))attach to multiple myeloma cells. It'll kill them and signal your immune system to attack them. You get this treatment if other ones haven't worked. You may have a reaction a few hours after getting the drug. This reaction may make you [cough](https://www.webmd.com/first-aid/coughs), wheeze, or have [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). You might also have a [runny nose](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/postnasal-drip)and [headache](https://www.webmd.com/migraines-headaches/default.htm). You could even get a [rash](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/common-rashes). If one of these happens to you, your doctor may adjust your dose or frequency or add another medicine to lessen or stop your symptoms. [Elotuzumab](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-170558/elotuzumab-intravenous/details)( [Empliciti](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-170564/empliciti-intravenous/details))is a monoclonal antibody that attaches to the SLAMF7 protein to kill multiple myeloma cells. It could make you [cough](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/rm-quiz-nighttime-cough), wheeze, or have [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems). You might also have a runny nose and [headache](https://www.webmd.com/migraines-headaches/migraines-headaches-basics)and [fever](https://www.webmd.com/first-aid/fevers-causes-symptoms-treatments)or get a respiratory tract infection. You could even get a rash. You might feel super [tired](https://www.webmd.com/sleep-disorders/ss/slideshow-fatigue-causes-and-remedies)or have weakness or numbness in your hands and [feet](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/guide/foot-pain-causes-and-treatments). And you might have [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea). [Isatuximab](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-178921/isatuximab-irfc-intravenous/details)( [Sarclisa](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-178927/sarclisa-intravenous/details)) also binds to myeloma cells and kills them. This is for people who have tried at least two different treatments before this one. You could have a reaction after this drug, as well. You could have trouble breathing, a cough, chills, or nausea. Other common side effects include diarrhea, pneumonia, anemia (low red blood cell count), upper respiratory infection, and thrombocytopenia (low blood platelet count). [Selinexor](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/search?type=drugs&query=SELINEXOR)( [Xpovio](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-177545/xpovio-oral/details)) is a drug known as a nuclear export inhibitor. [Teclistamab](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-185245/teclistamab-cqyv-subcutaneous/details)( [Tecvayli](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-185251/tecvayli-subcutaneous/details)) is a type of immunotherapy known as a bispecific T cell engager (BiTE). Clinical Trials There are some types of immunotherapy in development. You may want to ask your doctor about joining a [clinical trial](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/clincial-trial-guide-patients) so that you can try them. These include: Other adoptive cell therapies: Besides CAR-T cell therapy, other adoptive cell therapies that use your body's own T-cells to destroy the cancer are being developed including tumor-infiltrating lymphocyte (TIL) therapy. Checkpoint inhibitors: Drugs that reverse the checks and balances function in your immune system. They can turn on functions that are shut off (like stopping cancer cell growth) and turn off others (like the ones that help cancer cells grow. Cytokines: These messenger molecules control immune system growth and activity. [Monoclonal antibodies](https://www.webmd.com/colorectal-cancer/new-drugs-avastin-erbitux): These human-made molecules target antigens, or substances that make your immune system react, on tumors. Oncolytic virus therapies: These treatments use a modified virus to kill cancer cells and boost your immune response against the cancer. [Vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/ss/slideshow-vaccine-preventable-diseases): They work like more-common [vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/vaccines/default.htm) to jump-start the immune system to attack cancer cells.
